anchor.surface_text: Taking the case of the Company under s. 20 first, we have to see whether the Company has acquired Adhivasi rights thereunder. The relevant part of s.20 for our purposes is as follows Every person who-  a   b  was recorded as occupant,- of any land  other than grove land or land to which s. 16 applies  in the Khasra or khatauni of 1356 F, prepared under ss. 28 and 33 respectively of the U. P. Land Revenue Act, 1901, or who was on the date immediately preceding the date of vesting entitled to regain possession thereof under el.  e  of sub-s.  1  of s. 27 of the United Provinces Tenancy  Amendment  Act, 1947, or  ii  shall unless he has become a bhumidar of the land under sub-s.  2  of s-18 or an asami under el.  h  of s. 21, be called adhivasi of the land and shall, subject to the provisions of this Act, be entitled to take or retain possession thereof

concepts.interpretation: Person recorded as occupant in 1356 F khasra/khatauni (not grove or s.16 land) becomes adhivasi entitled to possession unless became bhumidar or asami otherwise.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: econdly, it is urged that as the Company was recorded as a thekadar in 1356 F, its possession was number on its own behalf but on behalf of the landlo

P. Land Revenue Act, 1901  ii  shall unless he has become Bhumidhar of the land under sub-s.  2  of s. 18 or an asami under cl.  h  of s. 21 be called Adhivasi of the land and shall, subject to the provision of this Act, be entitled to take or retain possession thereof.

concepts.interpretation: Benefit tied to record as occupant, not mere fact of occupation; entry as Thekadar means possession on behalf of lessor, not own right.

anchor.surface_text: Section 232 of the Act gives right to an Adhivasi to whom cl.  b  of s. 20 applies to apply within thirty months from the date of vesting to the Assistant Collector in-charge of the Sub-Division for putting him in possession of the land of which he is the Adhivasi. The question therefore that arises is whether the Company was recorded as occupant of the land in dispute which is undoubtedly not grove land or land to which s. 16 applies. The word  occupant  used in this part of the Act is not a term of art and has not been defined anywhere in the Act or in the U. P. Tenancy Act or in the Land Revenue Act. It must therefore be given its ordinary dictionary meaning which is a person in occupation .

concepts.interpretation: Ordinary dictionary meaning: a person in occupation; limitation from judicial decisions: in own right, not on behalf of someone else; possession under stay orders or as thekadar post-expiry does not negate own right.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: t case a receiver had been appointed and the person recorded in occupation of the land was held to be the agent of the receiver. Reliance was also pla

concepts.unlisted_description: Key term in s.20(b) U.P. Zamindari Act for adhivasi rights

anchor.surface_text: The Khasra and Khatauni have been produced before us and they show that the Upper Ganges Sugar Mills Ltd., has been recorded as in possession of the land in dispute. They also show however that the possession was as a Thekadar . What we have to ask ourselves is, whether these entries in the Khasra or Khatauni justify the conclusion that the Company has been recorded as an occupant within the meaning of s. 20 b . The word occupant has not been defined in the Act and it has to be properly interpreted on a consideration of the entire scheme and the purpose of the legislation.

concepts.interpretation: Connotes person in possession in own right, not on behalf of someone else; entry as Thekadar records possession on behalf of lessor.

anchor.surface_text: Looking at the entries before us I find that they record the Upper Ganges Sugar Mills possession as a Thekadar. Chapter XI of the U. P. Tenancy Act  U. P. XVII of 1939  deals with a Thekadar. It seems reasonable to hold that in this Chapter, Thekadar is equated to a farmer of rents, and Thekadars possession ordinarily is contemplated to be possession on behalf of his lessor.

concepts.interpretation: Equated to farmer of rents; possession ordinarily on behalf of lessor.

issues.text: Whether the Company has acquired Adhivasi rights under s. 20 of the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: Taking the case of the Company under s. 20 first, we have to see whether the Company has acquired Adhivasi rights thereunder. The relevant part of s.20 for our purposes is as follows Every person who- a b was recorded as occupant,- of any land other than grove land or land to which s. 16 applies in the Khasra or

issues.text: Whether the Company was recorded as occupant of the land in dispute which is not grove land or land to which s. 16 applies in the Khasra or khatauni of 1356 F

anchor.surface_text: The question therefore that arises is whether the Company was recorded as occupant of the land in dispute which is undoubtedly not grove land or land to which s. 16 applies. The word occupant used in this part of the Act is not a term of art and has not been defined anywhere in the Act or in the U. P. Tenancy Act or in the Land Revenue Act. It must therefore be given its ordinary dictionary meaning which is a person in occupation .

issues.text: Whether the Company's possession after the ejectment decree dated November 3, 1948 but continued under stay orders from appellate courts was in its own right or on behalf of the court

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the landlords however contends that the Company was not in possession in its own right and his argument in this connection is two-fold. Firstly, it is submitted that the Company was ordered to be ejected on November 3, 1948, which was in 1356 F. Thereafter it remained in possession because of the stay orders passed by the appellate courts to which it went in appeal successively. Therefore even though the Company was in occupation throughout 1356 F its possession after November 3, 1948 was not on its own behalf but on behalf of the Court.

issues.text: Whether the revenue records of 1356 F recording the Company as a thekadar indicate occupation on behalf of the landlords and not in its own right for the purposes of s. 20(b)

anchor.surface_text: The next argument on behalf of the landlords is that as the Company was recorded as a thekadar in 1356 F in the revenue records it must be held to have remained in possession on behalf of the landlords whose thekadar it was. In this connection reliance was placed on Lala Nanak Chand v. The Board of Revenue, U. P., where it was held that what s. 20 b requires is that there should be an entry of a persons name as an occupant in the khasra or khatauni of 1356 F but it is not necessary that the person recorded as an occupant should also have been in actual possession.

issues.text: Whether these entries in the Khasra or Khatauni justify the conclusion that the Company has been recorded as an occupant within the meaning of s. 20(b)

anchor.surface_text: The Khasra and Khatauni have been produced before us and they show that the Upper Ganges Sugar Mills Ltd., has been recorded as in possession of the land in dispute. They also show however that the possession was as a Thekadar. What we have to ask ourselves is, whether these entries in the Khasra or Khatauni justify the conclusion that the Company has been recorded as an occupant within the meaning of s. 20 b . The word occupant has not been defined in the Act and it has to be properly interpreted on a consideration of the entire scheme and the purpose of the legislation.

issues.text: Whether the Company is entitled to the benefit of s. 12 of the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 as a hereditary tenant

anchor.surface_text: In this connection we may point out that the Company claimed that it was entitled to possession not only as an Adhivasi under s. 20 but also as a hereditary tenant under s. 12, which provides that a thekadar under certain circumstances becomes a hereditary tenant. To meet the Companys case under s. 12 the landlords contended that the Company was not a thekadar in 1356 F because the theka expired on June 30, 1948.

What we have to ask ourselves is, whether these entries in the Khasra or Khatauni justify the conclusion that the Company has been recorded as an occupant within the meaning of s. 20 b . arguments.court_reasoning: Majority disagreed; held entry does not preclude own right given theka expiry

holdings.text: the Company was recorded as an occupant in 1356 F and that the nature of that occupation was on its own behalf and was not either on behalf of the court or on behalf of the landlords. Therefore the Company would be entitled to Adhivasi rights.

anchor.surface_text: Under the circumstances we are of opinion that the companypany was recorded as an occupant in 1356 F and that the nature of that occupation was on its own behalf and was not either on behalf of the companyrt or on behalf of the landlords. Therefore the Company would be entitled to Adhivasi rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied s.20(b) to facts: recorded in khasra/khatauni as in possession; nature determined from context including theka expiry, stay orders not altering right, entry not conclusive of representative possession.

holdings.text: the possession of the Company, though it continued because of the stay orders, cannot be held to be on behalf of the court and it must be in occupation in the right asserted by it

anchor.surface_text: In such circumstances the possession of the Company, though it continued because of the stay orders, cannot be held to be on behalf of the companyrt and it must be in occupation in the right asserted by it, even though if it had not obtained the stay orders it would not have remained in possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stay orders permit continuation of prior possession in asserted own right; distinguished cases with receivers or redelivery; rejected Board decision in Birjlal v. Murli Pd. as incorrect.

holdings.text: the contention on behalf of the landlords that we cannot look beyond the entry of the Company as a thekadar and must hold on that basis that it was in possession on behalf of the landlords, is incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the contention on behalf of the landlords that we cannot look beyond the entry of the Company as a thekadar and must hold on that basis that it was in possession on behalf of the landlords, is incorrect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Revenue entries do not record nature of possession (own right vs. behalf of another); landlords' contradictory stance on theka expiry for s.12; entry continues post-termination without change order.

holdings.text: it is not necessary to decide whether the Company, is also entitled to the benefit of s. 12.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the Company would be entitled to Adhivasi rights. On this view it is not necessary to decide whether the Company, is also entitled to the benefit of s. 12.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entitlement under s.20 suffices; no need to address alternative claim.

holdings.text: the only limitation that has been placed by judicial decisions on this meaning of the word occupant is that the person should be in occupation in his own right and not on behalf of someone else.

anchor.surface_text: The only limitation that has been placed by judicial decisions on this meaning of the word occupant is that the person should be in occupation in his own right and not on behalf of someone else. See Swami Prasad and another v. Board of Revenue, U. P.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopted interpretation from precedent (Swami Prasad); applied dictionary meaning with judicial gloss.

ORDER OF COURT. In view of the majority Judgment the appeals are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Judicial holding on the meaning of 'occupant' constrains the application of Section 16 by requiring occupation in own right
Holding interprets and limits the meaning of 'occupant', which is central to the issue of whether the Company was recorded as occupant

anchor.surface_text: The only limitation that has been placed by judicial decisions on this meaning of the word occupant is that the person should be in occupation in his own right and not on behalf of someone else. See Swami Prasad and another v. Board of Revenue, U. P.
ORDER OF COURT. In view of the majority Judgment the appeals are dismissed.
